events.originalText: Under the belief that Israel and the United States were planning to attack its nuclear program, Iran conducted the Great Prophet III missile test and war games exercise.
events.subtitle: Nuclear program of Iran
events.headline: Iran conducts Great Prophet III missile test amid fears of attack from Israel and the United States

events.originalText: Sri Lankan Civil War: After advising civilians to take shelter in places of worship, the Sri Lanka Air Force bombed a church in Navaly, killing at least 147 people.
events.subtitle: Sri Lankan Civil War
events.headline: Sri Lanka Air Force bombs church in Navaly, killing at least 147 civilians

events.originalText: Nintendo released the arcade game Donkey Kong (cabinet pictured), which featured the debut of Mario, one of the most famous characters in video-game history.
events.subtitle: Nintendo
events.headline: Nintendo releases Donkey Kong arcade game, debuting iconic character Mario

events.originalText: The United States conducted the Starfish Prime high-altitude nuclear test, the largest nuclear explosion in outer space.
events.subtitle: Starfish Prime
events.headline: United States conducts Starfish Prime high-altitude nuclear test in outer space

events.originalText: In a seminal moment for pop art, Andy Warhol's Campbell's Soup Cans exhibition opened at the Ferus Gallery in Los Angeles.
events.subtitle: Pop art
events.headline: Andy Warhol's Campbell's Soup Cans exhibition opens in Los Angeles

events.originalText: An earthquake struck Lituya Bay, Alaska; the subsequent megatsunami, the largest in modern times, reached an elevation of 1,720 ft (524 m).
events.subtitle: 1958 Lituya Bay earthquake and megatsunami
events.headline: Lituya Bay earthquake triggers largest modern megatsunami reaching 1,720 ft

events.originalText: Albert Einstein, Bertrand Russell (pictured) and nine other preeminent intellectuals and scientists issued the Russell–Einstein Manifesto, calling for a conference to assess the dangers posed by weapons of mass destruction.
events.subtitle: Albert Einstein
events.headline: Albert Einstein and Bertrand Russell issue Russell-Einstein Manifesto on weapons of mass destruction

events.originalText: Nitrate film being stored in a 20th Century Fox facility spontaneously combusted, destroying more than 40,000 reels of negatives and film prints.
events.subtitle: Nitrocellulose
events.headline: Nitrate film fire destroys 40,000 reels at 20th Century Fox facility

events.originalText: Politician William Jennings Bryan made his Cross of Gold speech advocating bimetallism, considered one of the greatest political speeches in American history.
events.subtitle: William Jennings Bryan
events.headline: William Jennings Bryan delivers Cross of Gold speech advocating bimetallism

events.originalText: The inaugural Wimbledon Championship, the world's oldest tennis tournament, began in London.
events.subtitle: 1877 Wimbledon Championship
events.headline: Inaugural Wimbledon Championship tennis tournament begins in London

events.originalText: The Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution, including the Citizenship Clause and the Equal Protection Clause, was ratified by the minimum required twenty-eight states.
events.subtitle: Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution
events.headline: Fourteenth Amendment to US Constitution, including Citizenship and Equal Protection Clauses, ratified

events.originalText: Following Zachary Taylor's death, Millard Fillmore became president of the United States, the last member of the Whig Party to hold that office.
events.subtitle: Zachary Taylor
events.headline: Millard Fillmore becomes US president after Zachary Taylor's death

events.originalText: British explorer David Thompson posted a notice at the confluence of the Columbia and Snake Rivers (in modern Washington state, U.S.), claiming the area for Great Britain.
events.subtitle: David Thompson (explorer)
events.headline: David Thompson claims Columbia and Snake Rivers area for Great Britain

events.originalText: Russo-Swedish War: During the Battle of Svensksund in the Baltic Sea, the Swedish Navy captured a third of the Russian fleet.
events.subtitle: Russo-Swedish War (1788–1790)
events.headline: Swedish Navy captures third of Russian fleet in Battle of Svensksund

events.originalText: The Mozart family grand tour began, presenting child prodigies Maria Anna and Wolfgang (both pictured) in Western Europe.
events.subtitle: Mozart family grand tour
events.headline: Mozart family grand tour featuring child prodigies Maria Anna and Wolfgang begins in Western Europe

events.originalText: War of the Austrian Succession: French victory at the Battle of Melle enabled their subsequent capture of Ghent from the Austrian Netherlands.
events.subtitle: War of the Austrian Succession
events.headline: French victory at Battle of Melle leads to capture of Ghent in War of the Austrian Succession

events.originalText: The Virginia Governor's Council made John Punch the first legally recognized slave in England's North American colonies.
events.subtitle: Virginia Governor's Council
events.headline: John Punch becomes first legally recognized slave in England's North American colonies

events.originalText: An earthquake and subsequent tsunami struck the area around Sendai, Japan, leaving sand deposits up to 4 km (2.5 mi) inland.
events.subtitle: 869 Jōgan earthquake
events.headline: Sendai, Japan struck by earthquake and tsunami leaving sand deposits 4 km inland

events.originalText: An estimated 30,000 people died when a massive earthquake struck the Roman province of Phoenice.
events.subtitle: 551 Beirut earthquake
events.headline: Massive earthquake in Roman province of Phoenice claims estimated 30,000 lives
